commit_message:
SSL for communication between cinder and rabbitmq

Currently, Cinder can not be configured via Puppet to communicate with
rabbitmq using SSL. Most other puppet component already have this feature.
This commit enable this feature for Cinder.

Change-Id: I1525bb1d36d1d49c76e4b42b37ff17f0c5c98f57

commit_message:
Fix alt tenant id's issue in BaseV2MemberImageTest

BaseV2MemberImageTest gets alt_tenant_id in the wrong way when tenant
isolation is off. commit 9612e81d142e88782d4faf6a85e81967b5323908
introduced getting the tenant_id from credentials instance. This case
was missed. Fixing this involves completely removing the code that
caused lp#1320079.

Change-Id: Ic8585077b876f70353202f0f47184a18bca8083d
Closes-bug: #1320079
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tempest refs/changes/57/93857/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: cls.alt_tenant_id = cls.alt_img_client.tenant_id
deleted_lines: cls.alt_tenant_id = cls.isolated_creds.get_alt_creds().tenant_id alt_tenant_name = cls.os_alt.credentials['tenant_name'] identity_client = cls._get_identity_admin_client() cls.alt_tenant_id = identity_client.get_tenant_by_name( alt_tenant_name)['id']

commit_message:
SSL for communication between neutron and rabbitmq

Currently, Neutron can not be configured via Puppet to communicate with
rabbitmq using SSL. Most other puppet component already have this feature.
This commit enable this feature for Neutron.

Change-Id: Ie7a6218733562c4e89302ced169db6c53efadcf0

commit_message:
Move API parameter parsing from OpenStack API to engine

In commit 4169c1bd8ce4db0a794e22471994ea401b77b9c0, the API parameter
parsing was moved to the OpenStack API.  Since then, inputs to the CFN
API were not being validated, creating a security hole.

Change-Id: I21920591075bcefbe695316dab6605afd6f4ec64
Closes-Bug: #1317667

added_lines: import jsonimport sixclass EngineApiTest(HeatTestCase): def test_timeout_extract(self): p = {'timeout_mins': '5'} args = api.extract_args(p) self.assertEqual(5, args['timeout_mins']) def test_timeout_extract_zero(self): p = {'timeout_mins': '0'} args = api.extract_args(p) self.assertNotIn('timeout_mins', args) def test_timeout_extract_garbage(self): p = {'timeout_mins': 'wibble'} args = api.extract_args(p) self.assertNotIn('timeout_mins', args) def test_timeout_extract_none(self): p = {'timeout_mins': None} args = api.extract_args(p) self.assertNotIn('timeout_mins', args) def test_timeout_extract_negative(self): p = {'timeout_mins': '-100'} error = self.assertRaises(ValueError, api.extract_args, p) self.assertIn('Invalid timeout value', six.text_type(error)) def test_timeout_extract_not_present(self): args = api.extract_args({}) self.assertNotIn('timeout_mins', args) def test_adopt_stack_data_extract_present(self): p = {'adopt_stack_data': json.dumps({'Resources': {}})} args = api.extract_args(p) self.assertTrue(args.get('adopt_stack_data')) def test_invalid_adopt_stack_data(self): p = {'adopt_stack_data': json.dumps("foo")} error = self.assertRaises(ValueError, api.extract_args, p) self.assertEqual( 'Unexpected adopt data "foo". Adopt data must be a dict.', six.text_type(error)) def test_adopt_stack_data_extract_not_present(self): args = api.extract_args({}) self.assertNotIn('adopt_stack_data', args) def test_disable_rollback_extract_true(self): args = api.extract_args({'disable_rollback': True}) self.assertIn('disable_rollback', args) self.assertTrue(args.get('disable_rollback')) args = api.extract_args({'disable_rollback': 'True'}) self.assertIn('disable_rollback', args) self.assertTrue(args.get('disable_rollback')) args = api.extract_args({'disable_rollback': 'true'}) self.assertIn('disable_rollback', args) self.assertTrue(args.get('disable_rollback')) def test_disable_rollback_extract_false(self): args = api.extract_args({'disable_rollback': False}) self.assertIn('disable_rollback', args) self.assertFalse(args.get('disable_rollback')) args = api.extract_args({'disable_rollback': 'False'}) self.assertIn('disable_rollback', args) self.assertFalse(args.get('disable_rollback')) args = api.extract_args({'disable_rollback': 'false'}) self.assertIn('disable_rollback', args) self.assertFalse(args.get('disable_rollback')) def test_disable_rollback_extract_bad(self): self.assertRaises(ValueError, api.extract_args, {'disable_rollback': 'bad'})

implementation.

commit_message:
Enable H302 rule everywhere

This patch enables the use of the H302 hacking rule everywhere. With
one exception of the client class imports in clients.py, this
is intentionally ignored.

Change-Id: Ia0ef5e44a411ccd6e6c12f9cf64427a96e021b47

commit_message:
Add hacking import exception for service clients

This commit adds import exceptions to the service client imports.
The service clients are imported at the class level and it would be
a major effort to change this. However, we want to be enforcing H302
everywhere else. This commit adds an exception to allow importing the
service clients as classes.

Change-Id: Ife74539fe04e97740e45325140f407fd7476e1c7

commit_message:
Specify group os-apply-config for config resources

This will indicate to os-collect-config that this config
resource represents os-apply-config configuration data,
so it can only write out top-level config files for
os-apply-config data (or Heat::Ungrouped for backwards
compatibility).

Change-Id: I3552fdd6df8106ab83cfd17d5f4b137cf33fbc36
Related-Bug: #1299109

commit_message:
mongo: remove _id in inserted alarm changes

This change ensures that mongodb driver doesn't modify the alarm changes
dictionary when we insert a new alarm changes. To avoid the insertion
of the internal '_id' of mongodb.

Change-Id: I9bcd643c9dc55449141cee94ef6826784e81e4e5

commit_message:
Fix test_create_show_delete_security_group_rule

test_create_show_delete_security_group_rule is validating only
icmp protocol and not tcp/udp protocols. This patch does the
necessary change.

Change-Id: I63b79e5016a718bf3af6e1194a994ec68f6c0c4e
Closes-Bug: #1319176

commit_message:
skip hostname check test

The test currently does not runs on the gate,
but it would cause issue when we enable the instance validation.

New cirros image release or direct metadata api check might help.

Change-Id: I190bd86da2fa9a47f5bb349ab8889a2e83b6ff38
Implements: blueprint ssh-auth-strategy

commit_message:
Remove py3k module

This module is obsolete and has been dropped from oslo-incubator.
Use six instead (which is already done here).

Change-Id: I8e0b49cdfbddcf2d44a601ad06be2e75897905fc

See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. # """ Python2/Python3 compatibility layer for OpenStack """ import six if six.PY3: # python3 import urllib.error import urllib.parse import urllib.request urlencode = urllib.parse.urlencode urljoin = urllib.parse.urljoin quote = urllib.parse.quote parse_qsl = urllib.parse.parse_qsl unquote = urllib.parse.unquote unquote_plus = urllib.parse.unquote_plus urlparse = urllib.parse.urlparse urlsplit = urllib.parse.urlsplit urlunsplit = urllib.parse.urlunsplit SplitResult = urllib.parse.SplitResult urlopen = urllib.request.urlopen URLError = urllib.error.URLError pathname2url = urllib.request.pathname2url else: # python2 import urllib import urllib2 import urlparse urlencode = urllib.urlencode quote = urllib.quote unquote = urllib.unquote unquote_plus = urllib.unquote_plus parse = urlparse parse_qsl = parse.parse_qsl urljoin = parse.urljoin urlparse = parse.urlparse urlsplit = parse.urlsplit urlunsplit = parse.urlunsplit SplitResult = parse.SplitResult urlopen = urllib2.urlopen URLError = urllib2.URLError pathname2url = urllib.pathname2url

commit_message:
Fix creating trust on workbook creation

 * We used the wrong project name for creating the trust. 
   Now we are using project name from config

Closes bug: #1318603

Change-Id: I51d1da115b0e0e9551d0174c821ed2886f5a79d8

commit_message:
Remove redundant code on offset, limit parameters.

The API resource modules for secrets, orders and containers had logic to clean up
the provided offset and limit parameters for paged GET requests. However, this logic
is already provided in the model repositories that the API modules call to make the
list query, hence this code can be removed from the API modules.

Change-Id: Icd6c29156f3bf80582984dbeb1d35f14fd13272f

commit_message:
Fixes the Hyper-V agent individual ports metrics

Replaces aggregated metric values with separated values for each port.

Co-Authored-By: Adrian Vladu <avladu@cloudbasesolutions.com>

(cherry picked from commit 4559a5f381082dba30bb535b69deeb09135da680)

Change-Id: Ie946dff984ef53f014c6c57f8d1d5bb9c6e7596d
Closes-Bug: #1289007

With ML2 plugin and l2-pop mechanism driver, it's possible to locally
answer to the ARP request of the VM and avoid ARP broadcasting emulation
on overlay which is costly.
OVS table flows don't be able to generate ARP respond so I use ebtables
to generate them.

WIP: only the ebtables wrapper is coded.

Closes-Bug: #1237427
Change-Id: Ic28610faf2df6566d8d876fcd7aed333647970e2

commit_message:
Implement local ARP responder onto OVS agent

With ML2 plugin and l2-pop mechanism driver, it's possible to locally
answer to the ARP request of the VM and avoid ARP broadcasting emulation
on overlay which is costly.

When this functionality is enabled, the OVS flows logic evolves to [1].
This functionality was introduce in 2.1 OVS branch [2].

A README is added to describe l2-pop mechanism driver and the agents
particularities.

[1] https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Ovs-flow-logic#OVS_flows_logic_with_local_ARP_responder
[2] http://git.openvswitch.org/cgi-bin/gitweb.cgi?p=openvswitch;a=commitdiff;h=f6c8a6b163af343c66aea54953553d84863835f7

DocImpact: New OVS agent flag 'arp_responder' set to false by default
Closes-Bug: #1237427
Change-Id: Ic28610faf2df6566d8d876fcd7aed333647970e2

commit_message:
Fix missing reference to ceilometer sources.json file

The ceilometer element is trying to install a file that doesn't
exist anymore, which makes the gate fail. This change adds a check
so that we can ignore the file and continue if it doesn't exist
on disk - the gate will succeed, and we should still be compatible
with older versions of ceilometer which have this file.

The file was removed after the Icehouse release which drop v1 api.

Change-Id: I1ec8fbb06e3c26ee1560efc13470e8370149ff89
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-image-elements refs/changes/03/94303/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
make title check more explicit on failure

the title check used to compare for length of arrays, which meant
that if it failed it wasn't really clear why. Given that we know
the 7 titles we believe should exist (and we test for them later)
we can instead just do a direct comparison. This has the advantage
of making it much easier to figure out what they are missing in
their specification.

Change-Id: Ie913f00cfb07a153fc94c8e5b2225174da3674dd

commit_message:
Adds checking the existence of primary-nodes

Added new if-statements that check if primary-nodes exist for cluster.
Added new param that decide if role primary-controller should be created during
creating testing enviroment.
Added tests for primary-mong

Change-Id: If3f546d0d4ba2e3808a9425fd76407f798f63081
Closes-Bug: #1312602

commit_message:
Enable skipped tests from test_models.py

Enable test_modelbase_iteritems and test_modelbase_iter which were
always skipped. These tests need a mapped object instead of
ModelBase instance.

Refactor ModelBaseTest a bit - move creation of ModelBase and
ExtraKeysModel instances to setUp().

Refactor test_modelbase_iteritems and test_modelbase_iter
to check if we can iterate over columns and extra_keys.

Closes-Bug: #1312220

Change-Id: If1271e96f3be6bf77bb18d67ca16e3020b7b5cc8

values, someone has to remember to sync up or at least check if the

commit_message:
Trust tempest build intervals and timeouts

Tempest has it's own per-service build timeout and build interval
values, tailored for how the tests are expected to perform.

Devstack shouldn't be overriding these values with a global
one-size-fits-all approach since it's not realistic and it introduces
dual maintenance because when Tempest is updated with new default
values, someone has to remember to sync up or at least check if the
values in devstack are still reasonable.

For example, the Heat timeout is 1200 seconds in Tempest right now but
devstack has it set at 900 seconds.  Why?  Probably because 900 was OK
at one point in time but is no longer and Tempest was adjusted
accordingly but devstack is overriding that value which can lead to race
failures with timeouts.

We should leave the configuration to Tempest since it's much more
granular now with branchless Tempest and how everything is boxed in for
configuration.

This should also help with reliability of the check/gate queues since we
have a lot of timeout failures which are basically pointless to
fingerprint with elastic-recheck since they are so sporadic and generic
depending on system load at the time of failure.

Related-Bug: #1320617

commit_message:
Fail when ssl parameters are missing and rabbit_use_ssl is set to true

This commit causes the run to fail is rabbit_use_ssl parameter is set
to true but the ssl related parameters remains undef.

Change-Id: I3784839dca59a06c1155e845df5e62625ea668f0
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-nova refs/changes/08/93808/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
POC: Adjust wait_for_image_status timeout based on CPU idle averages

Aggressive hard-coded timeouts don't necessarily work well in a dynamic
test environment with concurrent test execution, so rather than assume
the default timeouts are good enough and intermittently fail when
something like high CPU usage can negatively impact those assumptions,
adjust the timeout when CPU idle is low (less than 25) and keep waiting
until the timeout is three times higher than it's original value.

Partial-Bug: #1320617

Change-Id: Ia7eea172b63725207b0a98ad631de76720e8da25
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tempest refs/changes/45/94245/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import psutil # NOTE(mriedem): Get the current CPU idle value before looping and then # if we timeout we can determine if we need to extend the timeout based # on CPU load while we were waiting. cpu_idle_start = psutil.cpu_times().idle # This is our initial timeout value which may change based on CPU idle. build_timeout = client.build_timeout # This is the total time waited before timing out. total_timeout = build_timeout if int(time.time()) - start >= build_timeout: # NOTE(mriedem): check the CPU idle value from the last time # we started waiting and if it's below a given threshold we # will adjust our timeout and keep waiting, else fail. To avoid # waiting forever, we give up once our adjusted timeout is more # than three times the original timeout. cpu_idle_current = psutil.cpu_times().idle cpu_idle_average = int((cpu_idle_start + cpu_idle_current) / 2) if (cpu_idle_average < 25 and (build_timeout / client.build_timeout) < 3): # adjust timeouts and continue cpu_idle_start = cpu_idle_current build_timeout += int(build_timeout / 2) LOG.debug('Adjusting build_timeout based on CPU idle ' 'average: %d' % cpu_idle_average) else: total_timeout += build_timeout message = ('Image %(image_id)s failed to reach %(status)s ' 'status within the required time (%(timeout)s s).' % {'image_id': image_id, 'status': status, 'timeout': total_timeout}) message += ' Current status: %s.' % image['status'] caller = misc_utils.find_test_caller() if caller: message = '(%s) %s' % (caller, message) raise exceptions.TimeoutException(message)
deleted_lines: if int(time.time()) - start >= client.build_timeout: message = ('Image %(image_id)s failed to reach %(status)s ' 'status within the required time (%(timeout)s s).' % {'image_id': image_id, 'status': status, 'timeout': client.build_timeout}) message += ' Current status: %s.' % image['status'] caller = misc_utils.find_test_caller() if caller: message = '(%s) %s' % (caller, message) raise exceptions.TimeoutException(message)

commit_message:
Specify correct constraint name for postgresql

The UniqueConstraint is not named 'name,' this causes postgres to fail
with the following error:
UTC ERROR: constraint "name" of relation "datastore_versions" does not
exist
The constraint name should be 'datastore_versions_name_key' in the case
of postgresql.

Since postgres isn't tested in trove's gate yet (Fix:
I53e7fa2729542b88b43cd3de51e15118adaeec57) this has been tested locally
to make sure it stack.sh (which runs trove-manage db_sync) works.

Co-Authored-By: Nikhil Manchanda <SlickNik@gmail.com>
Change-Id: I265925566b8e84d92c838cb3b39ad1f8502cd052
Related-Bug: #1321093
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/trove refs/changes/15/94315/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: uc = UniqueConstraint('name', table=datastore_versions)

commit_message:
Add index modifying methods

Add to openstack/common/db/sqlalchemy/utils.py
methods for modifying indexes:
- add_index
- drop_index
- change_index_columns
- index_exists
- column_exists

Add tests for these methods to TestUtils class
in tests/unit/db/sqlalchemy/test_utils.py

Change-Id: Ib7b2a1a8169fff803a925326703e71c014230a68
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo-incubator refs/changes/89/65689/10 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def _index_exists(migrate_engine, table_name, index_name): inspector = reflection.Inspector.from_engine(migrate_engine) indexes = inspector.get_indexes(table_name) index_names = [index['name'] for index in indexes] return index_name in index_names def _add_index(migrate_engine, table, index_name, idx_columns): index = Index( index_name, *[getattr(table.c, col) for col in idx_columns] ) index.create() def _drop_index(migrate_engine, table, index_name, idx_columns): if _index_exists(migrate_engine, table.name, index_name): index = Index( index_name, *[getattr(table.c, col) for col in idx_columns] ) index.drop() def _change_index_columns(migrate_engine, table, index_name, new_columns, old_columns): if _index_exists(migrate_engine, table.name, index_name): Index( index_name, *[getattr(table.c, col) for col in old_columns] ).drop(migrate_engine) Index( index_name, *[getattr(table.c, col) for col in new_columns] ).create() def modify_indexes(migrate_engine, data, upgrade=True): if migrate_engine.name == 'sqlite': return meta = MetaData() meta.bind = migrate_engine for table_name, indexes in data.iteritems(): table = Table(table_name, meta, autoload=True) for index_name, old_columns, new_columns in indexes: if not upgrade: new_columns, old_columns = old_columns, new_columns if migrate_engine.name == 'postgresql': if upgrade: _add_index(migrate_engine, table, index_name, new_columns) else: _drop_index(migrate_engine, table, index_name, old_columns) elif migrate_engine.name == 'mysql': _change_index_columns(migrate_engine, table, index_name, new_columns, old_columns) else: raise ValueError('Unsupported DB %s' % migrate_engine.name)

commit_message:
Glance: Make swift store parameters configurable

Make the following swift store parameters configurable:

* swift_store_auth_version
* swift_store_endpoint_type
* swift_store_container
* swift_store_create_container_on_put
* swift_store_large_object_size
* swift_store_large_object_chunk_size
* swift_enable_snet
* swift_store_multi_tenant
* swift_store_admin_tenants
* swift_store_region
* swift_store_ssl_compression
* swift_store_retry_get_count

This allows more flexible swift backend usage by Glance,
for example running in multi-tenant mode.

Change-Id: I8fa3a3c2099360efbe8425702541275210995775

commit_message:
Glance: Make API delayed delete configurable

Make the following variables configurable:

* delayed_delete
* scrub_time
* scrubber_datadir

provides partial support for delayed delete of image data.

Change-Id: Id1ac5b2f68a65ca82ea7e216b28c8bf95316ca4d

commit_message:
Glance: Make 'data_api' param configurable

The 'data_api' param can be set to 'glance.db.sqlalchemy.api' to
access metadata directly via sqlalchemy, or 'glance.db.registry.api'
to use the registry api.

Change-Id: I3d5efc7adca0915b4df2ba55e126022254e8861a

added_lines: {{#glance.data-api}} # If unset, defaults to 'glance.db.sqlalchemy.api' data_api = {{glance.data-api}} {{/glance.data-api}}

commit_message:
Glance: Make image_cache_dir configurable

Make the API param 'image_cache_dir' configurable.
Defaults to /mnt/state/var/lib/glance/image-cache.

Change-Id: Ice204334bc065253f2fb2ebf62f985ad2e037c2b

commit_message:
Glance: Make quotas configurable

Allow the following to be set:

* image_member_quota
* image_property_quota
* image_tag_quota
* image_location_quota
* user_storage_quota

bnemec: Update to get this out of draft status

Change-Id: I048678ac9f73b0622266290b7ff76232e872e236

Glance: Make tcp_keepidle configurable for API

Allow customising of 'tcp_keepidle' parameter. Useful
to match specific Load Balancer settings.

commit_message:
Glance: Make API's registry parameters configurable

Allow the following registry related param's values
to be set:

* registry_host
* registry_port
* registry_client_protocol
* registry_client_key_file
* registry_client_cert_file
* registry_client_ca_file
* registry_client_insecure
* registry_client_timeout
* metadata_encryption_key

Uses new hierarchical naming structure glance.api.<config_param>.

bnemec: Update to get out of draft status

Change-Id: I10aaa5c80ac6cbcd7cb480ea5b0769ed84e1099f

Glance: Make API versions configurable

Make the following Glance API params configurable:

* enable_v1_api
* enable_v2_api

commit_message:
Updates SELinux configuration in HDP images

Recent changes to the core diskimage-builder elements
  have caused some previous warnings/errors that were silent
  to surface.  These errors are breaking the generation of the
  CentOS HDP images.
The failure is caused by the fact that the HDP images did
  not have all the correct configuration in place to disable
  SELinux.  Disabling SELinux is required for the HDP platform.
This patch modifies the dependencies for the hadoop-hdp
  element in order to include a dependency on the
  disable-selinux element from diskimage-builder.
This patch removes the original SELinux configuration commands
  for HDP, since these were found to be incorrect.
This patch adds the disable-selinux element to the HDP
  plain image as well.
This patch also includes some element refactorings, moving
  some elements into element-deps for hadoop-hdp, since these
  are required elements for HDP.

Change-Id: Ie6e26b397d022ea813c5022071bf3752ab39fa82

WIP: Create endpoints for other services

os_cloud_config/keystone.py now has a method to register services
and endpoints for components other than Keystone.

Glance-like interface provides us with 'has_more_data' flag and

commit_message:
Fix AppCatalog to use 'marker' attribute for pagination

Glance-like interface provides us with 'has_more_data' flag and
'marker' pointing to the next page data set. That means that
AppCatalog should drop link to previous page of Applications as well
as current page number - they both are not supported by standard OS
api.

Also:
* do not pass category as a part of murano:index url, pass it as a
  part of query-string (as well as marker);
* refactor filling 'Latest Apps' section: inside get_context_data()
  remove invalid app_id-s from session (i.e. because those packages
  were deleted). This change is needed because we may no longer know
  all existing packages after a single request to AppCatalog
  IndexView.

Change-Id: Ia0f4adb5657de9fba67733705268eb80684c656c
Implements: blueprint normalize-dashboard-pagination
Closes-Bug: #1307990

Improve

Change-Id: If376cbe3597fb27e72644a669b48890f44441db3

commit_message:
sources.json no longer exists in ceilometer breaking builds

ceilometer removed support for the v1 API which removes the sources.json
file causing disk-image-create to fail building the overcloud control.

Closes-Bug: #1321175
Change-Id: I74cbc49d3df1f8661dee3b046a3d3dbdae760850

commit_message:
Fixing DeprecationWarning: BaseException.message

Accessing BaseException message attribute is deprecated since py2.6,
In several cases it generates a lot of error messages into the log
files.

"".join(map(str, operational_error.args)) looks like a working alternative.

Change-Id: I0f4753bb64dc08d43d5b4c7269342bc6b781254c
Partial-Bug: #1257530

However, the exceptions raised by # SQLAlchemy can differ when using unicode() and accessing .message. # An audit across all three supported engines will be necessary to # ensure there are no regressions. for pattern in _DUP_KEY_RE_DB[engine_name]: match = pattern.match(integrity_error.message) # FIXME(johannes): The usage of the .message attribute has been # deprecated since Python 2.6. However, the exceptions raised by # SQLAlchemy can differ when using unicode() and accessing .message. # An audit across all three supported engines will be necessary to # ensure there are no regressions. m = re.match(operational_error.message)

commit_message:
Publish correct gpfs attributes to cinder.conf

Three extra attributes were being published to cinder.conf when volume_driver
was set to gpfs.  This patch corrects this problem.

Closes-Bug: #1320372
Change-Id: I4e1290aeac92c56beaad0ebd0941afaf249469e2

commit_message:
ceilometer.conf configuration option missing os_auth_url

ceilometer-agent-centrol error connection keystone: \
Skip interval_task because Keystone error: \
Authorization Failed: Unable to establish connection to http://localhost:5000/v2.0/tokens

Fixed bug #1320951

Change-Id: I8f8851d78a6dbb7c38979caf25d2e16a3d4a43b3

Unit tests for TempestConf

Add unit tests for TempestConf class.
Small refactoring of fake resources and TempestConf.

Change-Id: Iae6b1322b372bebc086043d8bc0b5454f829222b

added_lines: # Copyright 2014: Mirantis Inc. # All Rights Reserved. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import httplib import mock from rally import exceptions from rally.verification.verifiers.tempest import config from tests import test class ConfigTestCase(test.TestCase): @mock.patch('rally.objects.deploy.db.deployment_get') @mock.patch('rally.verification.verifiers.tempest.config.osclients') def setUp(self, mock_osclients, mock_get): super(ConfigTestCase, self).setUp() mock_get.return_value = {'endpoints': [{'username': 'test', 'tenant_name': 'test', 'password': 'test', 'auth_url': 'http://test', 'permission': 'admin'}]} self.conf_generator = config.TempestConf('fake_deploy_id') #self.verifier.verification = mock.MagicMock() @mock.patch('six.moves.builtins.open') @mock.patch('rally.verification.verifiers.tempest.config.urllib2.urlopen') def test__load_img_success(self, mock_open, mock_urlopen): mock_result = mock.MagicMock() mock_result.getcode.return_value = httplib.OK mock_urlopen.return_value = mock_result mock_file = mock.MagicMock() mock_open.return_value = mock_file self.conf_generator._load_img() @mock.patch('rally.verification.verifiers.tempest.config.urllib2.urlopen') def test__load_img_notfound(self, mock_urlopen): mock_result = mock.MagicMock() mock_result.getcode.return_value = httplib.OK mock_urlopen.return_value = mock_result self.assertRaises(exceptions.TempestConfigCreationFailure, self.conf_generator.load_img)

commit_message:
kvm is deprecated, use qemu-system-x86_64 directly

qemu-kvm and kvm binaries are deprecated now and not installed anymore
on Debian with qemu 2. With this patch, we call qemu-system-x86_64 directly.
qemu-system-x86_64 exists on:
 - Ubuntu since Precise:
   http://packages.ubuntu.com/precise/amd64/qemu-kvm/filelist
 - Debian since Wheezy:
   https://packages.debian.org/wheezy/amd64/qemu-system/filelist
 - Fedora

Change-Id: I21c8f985198ac7e04b40ba200e95a3532d68c834

commit_message:
Revert "Datastore_versions.name shouldn't be unique"

This is a test, it looks like the gate is breaking on
trove-manage db_sync on tempest-dsvm-postgres-full

This reverts commit c04226eb4d0ea64c7cf190b858c09464b8e9e98f.

Change-Id: I07c639ee156982ef0b87da2f05fef14054824f76
Related-Bug: 1321093

git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/murano refs/changes/84/93584/10 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. Copyright 2014 Mirantis, Inc. Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain a copy of the License at http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations under the License. =========================== Murano API v1 specification =========================== Introduction ============ Murano Service API is a programmatic interface used for interaction with Murano. Other interaction mechanisms like Murano Dashboard or Murano CLI should use API as underlying protocol for interaction. Return codes and errors ======================= All REST API calls return the natural HTTP response codes for the operations, e.g. a successful GET returns a HTTP 200, a successful PUT returns a HTTP 201, a GET for a non-existent entity returns HTTP 404, unauthorized operations return HTTP 401 or HTTP 403, internal errors return HTTP 500. Response of POSTs and PUTs ========================== All POST and PUT requests by convention should return the created object (in the case of POST, with a generated ID) as if it was requested by GET. Authentication ============== All requests include a Keystone authentication token header (X-Auth-Token). Clients must authenticate with Keystone before interacting with the Murano service. Specifications ============== .. toctree:: :maxdepth: 3 murano-api murano-repository +----------+----------------------------------+----------------------------------+-------------------------+ | Method | URI | Description | Additional Header | +==========+==================================+==================================+=========================+ | POST | /environments/<id>/configure | Creating new configuration | X-Configuration-Session | | | | session | | +----------+----------------------------------+----------------------------------+-------------------------+

commit_message:
os-svc-enable: make map-services optional

map-services command doesn't exist on Ubuntu and Debian because
the service is already called as expected.

With this changes, enable_systemd_service() can be used  even if
the map-service command in not in the $PATH.

Change-Id: I014a23f7ce0cf13a3a535d1fb4f4a0757951b689

commit_message:
Datastore_versions.name shouldn't be unique

The name column in the datastore_versions table is not supposed
to be defined with a unique index. The migrate version 18 was
intended to fix this but the method used to correct the column
definition doesn't work. Added a migrate version 26 to use
UniqueConstraint.drop() instead.

After some discussion, it was decided that downgrade would be
a no-op because it is difficult to reliably create a unique
index on a column with data in it, and further, the column wasn't
supposed to be unique in the first place.

Change-Id: Ida552982de6702db6ed4d40c0167e7d542c0ded4
Closes-Bug: #1310834

commit_message:
Factor data out of _check_titles

The straight-line implementation style of this test method allows
inconsistencies in checking to creep in. Switch to a data-driven
approach.

Change-Id: I8cd2be14f4338413854042031cf41da534c11dcb
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-specs refs/changes/01/91801/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: TITLES = { 'Problem description': [], 'Proposed change': [ 'Alternatives', 'Security impact', 'Other end user impact', 'Performance Impact', 'Other deployer impact', 'Developer impact', ], 'Implementation': [ 'Assignee(s)', 'Work Items', ], 'Dependencies': [], 'Testing': [], 'Documentation Impact': [], 'References': [], } self.assertEqual(len(TITLES), len(titles)) for title in TITLES: self.assertTrue(title in titles, "Title '%s' not present" % title) self.assertEqual( len(TITLES[title]), len(titles[title]), "Title '%s' must have %d subtitles" % (title, len(TITLES[title]))) for subtitle in TITLES[title]: self.assertTrue( subtitle in titles[title], "Subtitle '%s' not present for title '%s'" % (subtitle, title))
deleted_lines: self.assertEqual(7, len(titles)) problem = 'Problem description' self.assertIn(problem, titles) self.assertEqual(0, len(titles[problem])) proposed = 'Proposed change' self.assertIn(proposed, titles) self.assertEqual(6, len(titles[proposed])) self.assertIn('Alternatives', titles[proposed]) self.assertIn('Security impact', titles[proposed]) self.assertIn('Other end user impact', titles[proposed]) self.assertIn('Performance Impact', titles[proposed]) self.assertIn('Other deployer impact', titles[proposed]) self.assertIn('Developer impact', titles[proposed]) impl = 'Implementation' self.assertIn(impl, titles) self.assertEqual(2, len(titles[impl])) self.assertIn('Assignee(s)', titles[impl]) self.assertIn('Work Items', titles[impl]) deps = 'Dependencies' self.assertIn(deps, titles) self.assertEqual(0, len(titles[deps])) testing = 'Testing' self.assertIn(testing, titles) self.assertEqual(0, len(titles[testing])) docs = 'Documentation Impact' self.assertIn(docs, titles) self.assertEqual(0, len(titles[docs])) refs = 'References' self.assertIn(refs, titles) self.assertEqual(0, len(titles[refs]))

commit_message:
Revert "switch to using auth_url instead of auth_host et al"

This reverts commit 6d252ac4841d66eb3ced83bdce09db0e16c7f9b2.

keystone_authtoken middleware has no config option for auth_url,
so the change breaks neutron-server from being able to contact the
correct keystone service (unless it runs on localhost,
which is what auth_host defaults to)

Related-Bug: #1319280
Change-Id: I41a2ecd0ada3ec59983fd408123b0f3570050bb1

commit_message:
Ensure we can read the kernel out.

If the kernel is restricted read (as a security measure) we may not be
able to read it without chmodding it.

Change-Id: Ib577705c27d8c351288334de03a7848cf49f2de9
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/diskimage-builder refs/changes/75/93475/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Ensure public/management VIP is running on host where HAproxy is working.

After 3 failures on given node, HAproxy will be stopped on that node.
After 120s corosync will reset fail-count for this resource, and
administrator can manually start resource again.

If no manually intervention is made, cluster will start this resource
after 15m (cluster-recheck-interval).

Related-Bug: 1320183
Change-Id: I0a236326a06bac79c91d8bab26298d7dccfb418f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-library refs/changes/68/94168/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/rally refs/changes/64/92364/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. Copyright 2014 Mirantis Inc. All Rights Reserved. Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain a copy of the License at http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations under the License. .. _plugins: .. contents:: Scenarios Plugins ================= Rally provides an opportunity to create and use custom benchmark scenario as plugin. Placement --------- Put plugin to the **/etc/rally/plugins/scenarios** or **~/.rally/plugins/scenarios** directory and it will be autoloaded. Module should have ".py" extension. Creation -------- Inherit class from `rally.benchmark.scenarios.base.Scenario` or its subclasses. Every atomic action place in separate function and wrap it with decorator **atomic_action_timer** from `rally.benchmark.scenarios.utils`. Pass action name as string argument to decorator, name should be unique for every atomic action. It also will be used to show and store results. Combine atomic actions into your benchmark method and wrap it with decorator **scenario** from `rally.benchmark.scenarios.base`. Sample ~~~~~~ You can run this sample to test plugin loaded and benchmark method results is stored correctly. :: from rally.benchmark.scenarios import base from rally.benchmark.scenarios import utils as scenario_utils import time class PluginClass(base.Scenario): test1_times = 1 test2_times = 1 @scenario_utils.atomic_action_timer("test1") def _test1(self, factor): time.sleep(PluginClass.test1_times * factor * 0.1) PluginClass.test1_times = PluginClass.test1_times + 1 @scenario_utils.atomic_action_timer("test2") def _test2(self, factor): if PluginClass.test2_times == 3: raise Exception time.sleep(PluginClass.test2_times * factor) PluginClass.test2_times = PluginClass.test2_times + 1 @base.scenario() def testplugin(self, factor=1): self._test1(factor) self._test2(factor) Usage ----- Specify class and benchmark method of your pluginon at the top level of benchmark task configuration file. If you need to pass some arguments to benchmark method, place it in **args** section of task configuration file. Sample ~~~~~~ :: { "PluginClass.testplugin": [ { "args": { "factor": 2, }, "runner": { "type": "constant", "times": 3, "concurrency": 1 }, "context": { "users": { "tenants": 1, "users_per_tenant": 1 } } } ] }

commit_message:
Propose: Cloning for VMware Datastore backed disks

Take advantage of the Glance VMware storage backend merged in Icehouse
to avoid fetching the image through the network for the Nova VMware
driver.

Related to blueprint vmware-clone-image-handler

Change-Id: I373ddacad8f3ea1c1e01d2f8c0bc17c80a123285
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/81/84281/6 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================================== Storage: Cloning for VMware Datastore backed disks ========================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/vmware-clone-image-handler Take advantage of the Glance VMware storage backend merged in Icehouse to avoid fetching the image through the network for the Nova VMware driver. Problem description =================== Currently, the VMware driver is consuming Glance APIs to fetch and push images while spawning and snapshoting virtual machines. It requires Nova to invoke the upload and download Glance operations which means that the bits will go through the network unless they are already cached. Proposed change =============== In Icehouse, the VMware backend storage was introduced in Glance: it gives the ability to store images in the VMware datastores. For a spawn operation, the Nova VMware driver should now be able to copy directly the image in the datastore using the vCenter primitive operation CopyDatastoreFile. For a snapshot operation, it should be able to copy the snapshot to the Glance folder and make the image ready. To summarize, this blueprint gives the ability to copy the image in the datastore directly instead of upload/downloading the bits. Alternatives ------------ None. Data model impact ----------------- None. REST API impact --------------- None. Security impact --------------- None. Notifications impact -------------------- None. Other end user impact --------------------- The user will have to specify the datastore folder where the Glance images are stored in the VMware configuration and this only for the snapshot case because the location is available with the Glance V2 API when the image has already been uploaded. Performance Impact ------------------ The performance optimization is the main value of this blueprint. The virtual machine will be created much more faster especially for large images. This only apply when the image is not already in the cache. Other deployer impact --------------------- The Glance folder needs to be configured: 'vmware_store_image_dir' which contains the images in Glance. Developer impact ---------------- None. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: Arnaud Legendre (arnaud) Work Items ---------- This blueprint is divived in three parts: 1. Integrate with the Image handler framework (which means that we should provide a default download image handler) 2. Provide a copy image handler which provides the performance optimization discussed above. 3. Add the required code to keep the snapshot in the array. Dependencies ============ This change requires the Image Handler framework to be merged (review: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/33409/ bp: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/image-multiple-location). Note: This work is the similar approach as https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/rbd-clone-image-handler for RBD. Testing ======= Current tests should work. If the copy fails, the image handler will fall back to the download. Spawning a VM using the copy both for spawn and snapshot should work but faster. Documentation Impact ==================== The new configuration 'vmware_store_image_dir' var needs to be documentated. Also, the Glance datastore containing the images (preferably NFS) should be mounted to each host otherwise the copy might not be as efficient as it should be. References ========== Same idea for RBD: * https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/rbd-clone-image-handler Initial Blueprint containing everything: * https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/image-multiple-location Image handler review: * https://review.openstack.org/#/c/33409/ Patches for this blueprint: * https://review.openstack.org/63975 * https://review.openstack.org/67606 * https://review.openstack.org/79493

commit_message:
Add a reference to the nova developer documentation

I've showed these docs to more people than I care to. It would be
extremely helpful to reference them in HACKING, which is generally
the first thing people read if they intend to hack.

commit_message:
Let kernel kill dead TCP connections

1) Kill dead tcp connections in a more effective way:
configure the keepalive routines to wait for 30 secs before sending
the first keepalive probe, and then resend it every 8 seconds.
If no ACK response is received for 3 tries, mark the connection
as broken.
(The defaults are 7200, 75, 9 respectively and provide a *very* poor logic
for dead connections tracking and failover as well)
http://tldp.org/HOWTO/TCP-Keepalive-HOWTO/usingkeepalive.html
2) Set report_interval to 60 seconds and service_down_time to 180
seconds for Nova to let kernel kill dead connections.
3) Fix missing report_interval param usage in nova class.
4) Provide a new openstack::keepalive class in order to configure
networking related sysctls during the 'netconfig' stage.
poke ci

Change-Id: Ic9d491f4904a5e665278027fc37254003c4b5172
Closes-Bug: #1289200
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobrelia@mirantis.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-library refs/changes/47/94147/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: nova_report_interval => $::nova_report_interval, nova_service_down_time => $::nova_service_down_time, nova_report_interval => $::nova_report_interval, nova_service_down_time => $::nova_service_down_time,

commit_message:
Add initial glossary

These are the (hopefully) least-controversial glossary terms from the
initial Etherpad (https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/sdk-glossary).

Additional terms will be added as they are solidified.

Change-Id: I656aef799d786b8e7cb81c452f0180580e142f4d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstacksdk refs/changes/83/87783/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Glossary ======== CLI Command-Line Client; a textual user interface compute The OpenStack Compute API (Nova). container One of the object-store resources; a container holds objects being stored endpoint A base URL used in a REST request. An authentication endpoint is specifically the URL given to a user to identify a cloud. A service endpoint is generally obtained from the service catalog. host A physical computer. Contrast with 'node' identity The OpenStack Identity API (Keystone). image The OpenStack Image API (Glance). Also the attribute name of the disk files stored for use by servers. keypair The attribute name of the SSH public key used in the Compute API for server auth. node A logical system, may refer to a server (virtual machine) or a host. Generally used to describe an OS instance where a specific process is running, i.e. a 'network node' is where the network processes run, and may be directly on a host or in a server. Contrast with 'host'. object Another generic term, the default here is in the Python sense. The Object Store service (Swift) also uses 'object' as the name of the thing being stored. object-store The OpenStack Object Store API (Swift). project The attribute name of the owner of resources in an OpenStack cloud. Still refered to as tenant in some OpenStack projects. region The attribute name of a partitioning of cloud resources. resource A Python object representing an OpenStack resource inside the SDK code. (there is more here, specify attributes) role A personality that a user assumes when performing a specific set of operations. A role includes a set of rights and privileges. A user assuming that role inherits those rights and privileges. In the OpenStack Identity Service, a token that is issued to a user includes the list of roles that user can assume. Services that are being called by that user determine how they interpret the set of roles a user has and to which operations or resources each role grants access. It is up to individual services such as the Compute service and Image service to assign meaning to these roles. As far as the Identity service is concerned, a role is an arbitrary name assigned by the user. server The attribute name of the virtual machine resources. service In OpenStack this refers to a service/endpoint in the ServiceCatalog. It could also be a collection of endpoints for different regions. A service has a type and a name. service catalog The list of services configured at a given auth endpoint available to the authenticated user. tenant See 'project'. 1) The deprecated name of the owner of resources in an OpenStack cloud. 2) A container used to group or isolate resources and/or identity objects. Depending on the service operator, a tenant can map to a customer, account, organization, or project. token An arbitrary bit of text that is used to access resources. Each token has a scope that describes which resources are accessible with it. A token may be revoked at anytime and is valid for a finite duration. While the OpenStack Identity Service supports token-based authentication in this release, the intention is for it to support additional protocols in the future. The intent is for it to be an integration service foremost, and not aspire to be a full-fledged identity store and management solution. volume The OpenStack Volume API (Cinder). Also the attribute name of the virtual disks.

commit_message:
Make cinder-tgt/lio depend on cinder-volume

The iscsi helper is only used for cinder-volume nodes, so it makes
sense for these elements to depend on it directly so users can
s/cinder-volume/cinder-[tgt|lio]/ in their image builds.

Change-Id: I7468c7516a65d7b4e462e14022e5f43cfcc827e7

commit_message:
debug level logs should not be translated

According to the OpenStack translation policy available at
https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/LoggingStandards debug messages
should not be translated. Like mentioned in several changes in
Nova by garyk this is to help prioritize log translation.

Partial-Bug: #1317950

Change-Id: Ic8b19ec49441e49492ea5c43475fc946e20057fe

commit_message:
Allow vlan type usage for OpenDaylight ml2

The initial OpenDaylight integration with Openstack did not support
vlan isolation so it was not included as a valid type. This change
adds the vlan type as allowed.

Also modified tests to include vlan as supported in the
check_segment().

DocImpact:
Use of VLANs with ML2 and the OpenDaylight mechanism driver
requires OpenDaylight Helium or newer to be installed.

Closes-Bug: #1315475
Change-Id: I52e3c9bfdc93b8786c58954beca105e7498e3f40
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/44/91844/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: constants.TYPE_VXLAN, constants.TYPE_VLAN]

commit_message:
ceph::osd : do not hardcode the cluster name

And cleanup the content of the OSD when it is removed, before umounting it.

Change-Id: Ie255d4ae4012b995fd2fc0e6f643ed32a03ce165
Signed-off-by: Loic Dachary <loic@dachary.org>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-ceph refs/changes/55/90555/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if $cluster { $cluster_name = $cluster } else { $cluster_name = 'ceph' } rm -fr /var/lib/ceph/osd/${cluster_name}-\$id/* umount /var/lib/ceph/osd/${cluster_name}-\$id || true rm -fr /var/lib/ceph/osd/${cluster_name}-\$id

commit_message:
ceph::mon : control client.admin key generation

Creating an empty /etc/ceph/ceph.client.admin.keyring file disables the
automatic creation of the client.admin credentials when the first
monitor is created.

The creation of the key must be done via ceph::key, using the
mon. keyring, in the same way ceph-create-keys does.

Modify the client.volumes test to actually use cephx instead of
injecting a key in a non cephx cluster. It makes the client.something
test redundant and also demonstrates that the client.admin key can be
created by puppet instead of being automatically created by
ceph-create-keys.

Change-Id: I7060e418c27ea3f6f4e53604044f21865438382e
Signed-off-by: Loic Dachary <loic@dachary.org>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-ceph refs/changes/51/89351/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: $cluster_name = $cluster $cluster_option = "--cluster ${cluster_name}" } else { $cluster_name = 'ceph' # prevent automatic creation of the client.admin key by ceph-create-keys exec { "ceph-mon-${cluster_name}.client.admin.keyring-${id}": command => "/usr/bin/touch /etc/ceph/${cluster_name}.client.admin.keyring", } ->

commit_message:
NSX: do not raise on missing router during migration step

Return None for missing router rather raising NotFound exception;
this is what the client code was expected to handle in the first
place.

Closes-bug: 1313918

Change-Id: I573770a69d0170b027fc990c29aaa87b1fc8eccc
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/24/90824/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: return None

commit_message:
NSX: fix error when creating VM ports on subnets without dhcp

The error was caused by a missing LSN port (which is created when
the subnet is setup with dhcp enabled). Therefore, check the port
is in place before proceeding with the setup.

Change-Id: I658ead0c324a24ad3f061844ecac13cd3359d341
Closes-bug: 1316365
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/74/92274/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: lsn_id, lsn_port_id = self.lsn_port_get( context, network_id, subnet_id, raise_on_err=False) try: if lsn_id and lsn_port_id: hdlr(self.cluster, lsn_id, lsn_port_id, data)
deleted_lines: lsn_id = None lsn_port_id = None try: lsn_id, lsn_port_id = self.lsn_port_get( context, network_id, subnet_id) hdlr(self.cluster, lsn_id, lsn_port_id, data)

commit_message:
Add profiling middleware in Swift

The profile middleware provide a tool to profile Swift
code on the fly and collect statistic data for performance
analysis. An native simple Web UI is also provided to help
query and visualize the data.

Change-Id: I6a1554b2f8dc22e9c8cd20cff6743513eb9acc05
Implements: blueprint profiling-middleware
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/swift refs/changes/70/53270/32 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: pipeline = profile healthcheck recon object-server # Note: Put it at the beginning in the pipleline. [filter:profile] use = egg:swift#profile log_filename_prefix = /opt/stack/data/swift/profile/p1/object.profile # This prefix will be used to combine process id and time stamp to name the # profile data file. dump_interval = 5 # the profile data will be dumped to local disk based on above naming rule # in this interval. dump_timestamp = false # Be careful, this option will enable profiler to dump data into the file with # time stamp which means there will be lots of files piled up in the directory. path = /__profile__ # This is the path of the URL to access the mini web UI. flush_at_shutdown = false # Clear the data when the wsgi server shutdown. unwind = false # unwind the iterator of applications

commit_message:
Reference new get_engine() method from wsgi.py

wsgi.py referenced get_engine in neutron.openstack.common.db.sqlalchemy.session.
This method was removed from that file in commit 53609f29f3c8fcadc545afb891189253c07b33c3
change-id I0e1d86878d3eb924b01e04dced0f90b4e57757d8. This patch references the
replacement method added to neutron.db.api.

Closes-Bug: #1314850
Change-Id: Ifd4db5f49e2aaebc67eccb8bdcef8eea54983112
(cherry-picked from commit 07a130be1a1f77fc86076f37afe5b6bae2692a2c)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/67/94267/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Ensure tenant owns devices when creating a gateway

This patch adds an ownership check in the create_gateway method.
This kind of check can hardly be enforced leveraging the policy engine.

Change-Id: Iffdc9c570d688f824374281b37efd23761883d26
Closes-Bug: 1319583
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/43/93643/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Use /taskflow/flush-test in the flush function

Instead of using /tmp use a taskflow specific
directory for the flush testing utility function
to make it possible to cleanup any leftover taskflow
test directories if/when a test crashes or fails without
cleaning itself up.

Change-Id: I4d06adf9b9fbf9ec70b511e763edb52a41293e39
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/taskflow refs/changes/92/93192/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

Adding tenant-id while creating Radware ADC service

with tenant as a parameter

"""Set up the API server application instance.""" import flask from oslo.config import cfg from ceilometer.api.v1 import blueprint as v1_blueprint from ceilometer.openstack.common import jsonutils from ceilometer import storage class JSONEncoder(flask.json.JSONEncoder): @staticmethod def default(o): return jsonutils.to_primitive(o) def make_app(conf, attach_storage=True, sources_file='sources.json'): app = flask.Flask('ceilometer.api') app.register_blueprint(v1_blueprint.blueprint, url_prefix='/v1') app.json_encoder = JSONEncoder try: with open(sources_file, "r") as f: sources = jsonutils.load(f) except IOError: sources = {} @app.before_request def attach_config(): flask.request.cfg = conf flask.request.sources = sources if attach_storage: @app.before_request def attach_storage(): flask.request.storage_conn = \ storage.get_connection_from_config(conf) return app # For documentation app = make_app(cfg.CONF, attach_storage=False)

commit_message:
Don't translate debug level logs

Our translation policy
(https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/LoggingStandards#Log_Translation) calls
for not translating debug level logs. This is to help prioritize log
translation. Furthermore translation has a performance overhead, even if
the log isn't used (since nova doesn't support lazy translation yet).

Add a local hacking rule to enforce this.

Change-Id: I6c7b8c74cff0c9b5ec278281e7721cca1fc2f3c1

commit_message:
NSX: pass the right argument during metadata setup

The NSX cluster was erroneously passed instead of context.
This patch addressed that and tweaks UT to verify the right
parameter is passed instead.

Change-Id: Ife660b3a23705342043d121c7dcecad43e22abc1
Closes-bug: #1315538
(cherry picked from commit a3a8a86d7bccb824725d91735bd032237786f5aa)

commit_message:
Only top-level some deployment configs

Only config which contains os-apply-config data should be written
to the top level config structure. This change will only top-level
configs which are in the group os-apply-config or the default group
Heat::Ungrouped.

This tripleo-heat-templates change will specify a group for all
config resources https://review.openstack.org/#/c/91731/ however
the expected top-levels will still be written out without this
change.

This change is to fix heat software config when the config is not
json.

Change-Id: I16e42825121cf4968d4b0f0d266f4f6daa962921
Closes-Bug: #1299109

commit_message:
Add an example which uses the run iteration functionality

Create an example which can run many engines at once using many
engines, each with its own iterator that can be used in a single
loop to cause that engine to progress to its next state.

Change-Id: I8c6ca19a752f4ced77fd86727f17ecad8c8e72c8

subject: Make nova-novncproxy usable in a public cloud.
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-04-18 14:11:56.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-image-elements/commit/b17209b6c2260f512b6627a96798d260a553c5c0', 'message': "Make nova-novncproxy usable in a public cloud.

This refactors the nova-novncproxy configuration in TripleO
so that it can be used in a cloud where the compute hosts
don't each have to be assigned a public IP. With the
new configuration the nova-novncproxy is configured
to run on the nova-api (controller) node which
typically will have a public IP assigned to it.

Specific changes include:

 -move novnc element to nova-novncproxy
 -move all the nova-novncproxy stuff out of nova-kvm into
  the new nova-novncproxy element
 -configures Fedora iptables rules to support noVNC
  connections on 6080
 -Adds a new nova.public_ip parameter which is used
  to construct the novncproxy_base_url. This may be
  returned directly to cloud users via
  'nova get-vnc-console' or consumed by Horizon.
 -Set vncserver_proxyclient_address to the real
  local(internal) IP address for the compute host.
  Previously we used 127.0.0.1 which won't work
  unless nova-novncproxy runs on the Nova compute host.
  To do this we use {{local-ipv4}} which should always
  be the Heat provided local management IP address
  for the compute host.

Change-Id: I18cdc36248749390f0ab1e2c454741dbf2736e7f
Closes-bug: #1309510

  'nova get-vnc-console' or consumed by Horizon.
 -Set vncserver_proxyclient_address to the real
  local(internal) IP address for the compute host.
  Previously we used 127.0.0.1 which won't work
  unless nova-novncproxy runs on the Nova compute host.
  To do this we use {{local-ipv4}} which should always
  be the Heat provided local management IP address
  for the compute host.

Change-Id: I18cdc36248749390f0ab1e2c454741dbf2736e7f
Closes-bug: #1309510
"}]
commit_message:
Make nova-novncproxy usable in a public cloud.

This refactors the nova-novncproxy configuration in TripleO
so that it can be used in a cloud where the compute hosts
don't each have to be assigned a public IP. With the
new configuration the nova-novncproxy is configured
to run on the nova-api (controller) node which
typically will have a public IP assigned to it.

Specific changes include:

 -move novnc element to nova-novncproxy
 -move all the nova-novncproxy stuff out of nova-kvm into
  the new nova-novncproxy element
 -configures Fedora iptables rules to support noVNC
  connections on 6080
 -Adds a new nova.public_ip parameter which is used
  to construct the novncproxy_base_url. This may be
  returned directly to cloud users via
  'nova get-vnc-console' or consumed by Horizon.
 -Set vncserver_proxyclient_address to the real
  local(internal) IP address for the compute host.
  Previously we used 127.0.0.1 which won't work
  unless nova-novncproxy runs on the Nova compute host.
  To do this we use {{local-ipv4}} which should always
  be the Heat provided local management IP address
  for the compute host.

Change-Id: I18cdc36248749390f0ab1e2c454741dbf2736e7f
Closes-bug: #1309510

commit_message:
Remove update_allowed_keys definition and usage

The update_allowed_keys attribute didn't really define any useful
policy, and prevented automatic update which should be handled by the
base Resource class like DeletionPolicy. This patch removes the usage
and the various definitions around the code base.

Change-Id: I78494aba07b6badeca8e95f1875ca8e4b9b0290c
Co-Authored-By: ala.rezmerita@cloudwatt.com
Partial-Bug: #1316171

commit_message:
eliminate the need for hplefthandclient in tests

In order to eliminate the need to have the hplefthandclient in the
global-requirements project, we need to remove the hplefthandclient
from being imported in all HP LeftHand driver unit tests in cinder.

Change-Id: I4009ea17b507b1deb2a567dd420f309e15aaf92d
Closes-Bug: #1316824

commit_message:
Add map-services for debian distros.

DIB's map-services is currently used in TIE's os-svc-config
binaries to support service name lookups. Many of the systemd
specific functions require bin/map-services to exist.

This change adds bin/map-services files that are noops
to both the debian and ubuntu elements so that as those
distros move towards using systemd they can make use
of the functions we already have in place.

Change-Id: If8d61f3858b11de86c3292e840d033e5e3cecedb

commit_message:
Sync running_deleted_instance_action for nova

* Sync running_deleted_instance_action=reap from nova upstream
  in order to make all instaces at compute nodes being consistent
  with the Nova DB state.
* In Havana release the default value was 'log' and that was a cause
  of the flopping nova-computes and their queues uncontrolled grow
  due to the DB inconsistent state.
See
https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/master/nova/compute/manager.py
poke ci

Closes-bug: #1317488

Change-Id: I6de6898ab2e1c7e327eea0cd79c82f4fa6a94bb0
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobrelia@mirantis.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-library refs/changes/27/93927/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # [running_deleted_instance_action] Action to take if a running deleted instance is detected (deleted in nova DB). Optional. # Defaults to 'reap'. $remote_syslog_server = '127.0.0.1', $running_deleted_instance_action = 'reap', nova_config { 'DEFAULT/running_deleted_instance_action': value => $running_deleted_instance_action; }

commit_message:
Use futures wait() when possible

Instead of always using our custom future wait
functionality, only use that functionality if there
are green futures and in other cases just use the
future wait() function instead.

Change-Id: I1eadcf53eb4b5f47b9543965610bfe04fec52e70

commit_message:
Using correct attribute of exception

Currently patch (https://review.openstack.org/#/c/69837/6) was merged in
python-novaclient. New exceptions have not attribute 'code' and now we
should use http_status instead, falling back to the old attribute if
the new attribute does not exist.

Change-Id: I16e54c8e19dd93229fd7bcfe124fd4f2595f4e59
Closes-bug: #1319499

commit_message:
Add a cachedproperty descriptor

It is pretty common that we create a property method that
checks if an instance variable is none, then creates it and
then sets the instance property (and then never gets called
to create it again, unless property is reset to none).

Apply this new property descriptor to a few places that are
redoing this same action over (don't repeat yourself principle
in action).

Change-Id: If6c20c5a2d145c51af3f3db56a4746eca8601253
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/taskflow refs/changes/08/92208/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import inspectclass cachedproperty(object): """Descriptor that can be placed on instance methods to translate those methods into properties that will be cached in the instance (avoiding repeated creation checking logic to do the equivalent). """ def __init__(self, wrapped): # If a name is provided (as an argument) then this will be the string # to place the cached attribute under if not then it will be the # function itself to be wrapped into a property. if inspect.isfunction(wrapped): self._wrapped = wrapped self._wrapped_attr = "_%s" % (wrapped.__name__) else: self._wrapped_attr = wrapped self._wrapped = None def __call__(self, fget): # If __init__ received a string then this will be the function to be # wrapped as a property (if __init__ got a function then this will not # be called). self._wrapped = fget return self def __get__(self, source, owner): print source try: return getattr(source, self._wrapped_attr) except AttributeError: setattr(source, self._wrapped_attr, self._wrapped(source)) return getattr(source, self._wrapped_attr)

commit_message:
Mask passwords that are included in commands

The current password masking doesn't scrub passwords from commands
that may be written to log files.  This commit adds support for
scrubbing passwords provided as options with commands, where the
tokens in the command are separated only by spaces.  There is a
separate commit for scrubbing passwords when the tokens are separated
by commas and wrapped in quotes.

Adds tests to ensure commands are properly sanitized.

Change-Id: Idc8d55d5ebcc4fc5a3f66efeff86b19c3d94e7e2
Closes-Bug: #1320712

commit_message:
Upgrade to cirros 0.3.2

Cirros 0.3.2 is fixing the host name setting issue, which
is required for turning on the tempest instance validation tests.

Change-Id: I1b87740ab02c4eb0a8df653a35e1f85d40abda51
Related-Bug: #1132686

commit_message:
Move all Secret metadata to SecretMetadatum table

This patch moves the Secret attributes to the SecretMetadatum table.
This change should not affect the user interface, but will allow for
specification of user-specified metadata in the future.  This is needed for
KMIP integration.

blueprint add-metadata-to-secrets
Change-Id: I194b9b9000edbeac8c3cef6cd9da2a095a5fc063

commit_message:
Add user modifiable column

If users are allowed to add their own metadata, we should specify whether or
not they can modify existing data.  The metadata generated during Secret
creation should not be modifiable by the user.  This prevents the user from
overwriting required metadata.

blueprint add-metadata-to-secrets

Change-Id: Ib31445498a92fc0c4ab9ea126344c0765837d1bb

commit_message:
Integration tests - base class for all tests

The TestCase class will be the base for all tests, except the login
tests.
It contains two methods:
setUp - opens the login page, and performs the login to allow all test
start from the home page.

tearDown - returns the driver to the home page and logs out.

https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Horizon/Testing/UI

Partially implements blueprint: selenium-integration-testing

Change-Id: I748174108844c26eab0d375dafcd1f429f0e83dc

commit_message:
Add support for showing assignee for openreviews

For some project, we would like to make clear the
reviewer assignee for reviews.
In this commit, we are going to add review_assignee_url for project json.
review_assignee_url is a pointer for assignee list csv file.
colums should be
review_url, primary, secondary

Change-Id: If0a9ea15b18d93aded91254c4de94bc753d3bf9d

commit_message:
Call policy.init() once per API request

This patch changes the policy engine behaviour and the API base
controller in order to ensure policy.init is invoked only once
for each API request.
This will avoid issues arising from policy file updates during
API processing and speed up response generation for list operations,
by about 5%.

This patch also removes an obsolete TODO comment.

Change-Id: I108ebd26fccdea19cb00959f70d87c3bc1587df9
Closes-Bug: 1302611
(cherry picked from commit 1d41ba485f060a4d6dbe0767845391f955247b08)

commit_message:
Add new configuration files for ceilometer

According to patch: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/77957/, and patch:
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/42713/15, new configuration files named
api_paste.ini and event_definitions.yaml are introduced, this patch
adds them to ceilometer configuration directory.

Change-Id: I57165d588da35f13b2d22629b48dc087502598a7

commit_message:
Workaround Fedora libvirtd issues on Xen instances

Fedora libvirtd fails to start on Xen instances (i.e. rackspace
instances) due to [1].  This works around the issue until it can be
fixed upstream.

[1] https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1098376

Change-Id: I3790b5025982730263a6a84fce596e80f09efd5a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack refs/changes/45/93845/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # workaround for https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1098376; # if we see the empty Xen proc file then remove the plugin # shared-libraries (yum remove would uninstall libvirt due to # dependencies, so let's avoid that...) if [[ is_fedora ]]; then if [ -f /proc/xen/capabilities ]; then if [ $(stat -c '%s' /proc/xen/capabilities) -eq 0 ]; then sudo rm /usr/lib64/libvirt/connection-driver/libvirt_driver_libxl.so sudo rm /usr/lib64/libvirt/connection-driver/libvirt_driver_xen.so # ensure it's not stuck sudo pkill libvirtd || true sleep 5 sudo service libvirtd start fi fi fi

commit_message:
BrcdFCSanLookupService should allow customize host key and policy

In BrcdFCSanLookupService, the initialization should allow the
customization of the known_hosts_file and missing_key_policy so that the
hosts key and missing policy can be customized according to the
different scenario and customer aspect. This will not change the default
behavior when no argument is given, but more flexible to allow the
caller to give more options according to different requirements.

Closes-Bug: #1320050
Change-Id: If5767f63ccd2cde5fbea30a6154acf4d28f662b6

commit_message:
Add a way to signal that tasks are delayed

In order to allow a task to be finished at some
later period, allow for tasks to signal this via
using a new DELAYED executor state that can be
returned during execution.

If a task raises a delayed exception then further
execution will continue (on all tasks which still
can be executed) and upon completion of those tasks
the engine will return that it is INCOMPLETE
will allow the engine to be resumed from later when
those incomplete tasks have completed.

Things to note: if a task raises a delayed exception
it will be restarted completly on restart, it will
not resume from the last delayed exception that is
thrown. This implies that a task that throws multiple
delayed exceptions at multiple points must track its
own state/progress to know how to deal with this.

Part of blueprint async-tasks

Change-Id: Ie6b64f8c8140be461914e9701f03de3a42867b68
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/taskflow refs/changes/77/84277/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: delayed = [] if event in (ex.EXECUTED, ex.REVERTED): self._complete_task(node, event, result) elif event == ex.DELAYED: self._complete_delayed(node) delayed.append(node) else: raise excp.ExecutionFailure("Unknown execution" " event: %s" % (event)) elif event == ex.REVERTED: else: raise excp.ExecutionFailure("Unknown execution failure" " event: %s" % (event)) elif delayed: return st.INCOMPLETE elif self._analyzer.get_next_nodes(): def _complete_delayed(self, task): self._task_action.complete_delayed(task) self.reset_retry(retry) self.reset_retry(retry) def reset_retry(self, retry): self._storage.set_atom_intention(retry.name, st.EXECUTE) self._reset_nodes(self._analyzer.iterate_subgraph(retry)) def reset_all(self): self._reset_nodes(self._analyzer.iterate_all_nodes()) def reset_incomplete(self): def incomplete_nodes_iter(): for node in self._analyzer.iterate_all_nodes(): if self._analyzer.get_state(node) == st.INCOMPLETE: yield node self._reset_nodes(incomplete_nodes_iter(), reset_progress=False) def _reset_nodes(self, nodes_iter, reset_progress=True): kwargs = {} if reset_progress: kwargs['progress'] = 0.0 self._task_action.change_state(node, st.PENDING, **kwargs)
deleted_lines: self._complete_task(node, event, result) else: if self._analyzer.get_next_nodes(): self._retry_subflow(retry) self._retry_subflow(retry) def reset_all(self): self._retry_subflow(None) def _retry_subflow(self, retry): if retry is not None: self._storage.set_atom_intention(retry.name, st.EXECUTE) nodes_iter = self._analyzer.iterate_subgraph(retry) else: nodes_iter = self._analyzer.iterate_all_nodes() self._task_action.change_state(node, st.PENDING, progress=0.0)

commit_message:
Move gcc to general

Lot of packages explicitly requires gcc now, but almost all of
the components needs it.

Always keep gcc in hand-range.

files/rpms/general: always installs the libxlst2-devel, not just on
RHEL 6, package recompile capability always handy and these are small
packages anyway.

Change-Id: Ia7d0e1938fb2453e3c02b979f99d6d179c6a24c6

commit_message:
Fedora: Add support for configuring Yum mirrors

Updates the fedora element so that DIB_DISTRIBUTION_MIRROR can
be used to configure a custom Yum mirror on Fedora. This
implementation replaces the baseurl in each of the default
Fedora Yum .repo files so that a custom mirror URL/path
can be supplied. The URL should point to the directory
where the updates and release directories exist. Example:

  http://download.fedoraproject.org/pub/fedora/linux

As part of this change we also remove any existing
metalink settings in the .repo files to cover the case
where an end user runs their own createrepo command
to create the mirror... which means your metadata won't match that
of the normal Fedora mirrors and your baseurl won't get used.

Change-Id: I1a49a2941b1cc489e91a72b87430393cd32e865d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/diskimage-builder refs/changes/90/92190/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: #!/bin/bash set -eu DIB_DISTRIBUTION_MIRROR=${DIB_DISTRIBUTION_MIRROR:-} [ -n "$DIB_DISTRIBUTION_MIRROR" ] || exit 0 for FILE in /etc/yum.repos.d/fedora.repo /etc/yum.repos.d/fedora-updates.repo /etc/yum.repos.d/fedora-updates-testing.repo; do sudo sed -e "s|^#baseurl=http://download.fedoraproject.org/pub/fedora/linux|baseurl=$DIB_DISTRIBUTION_MIRROR|" -i $FILE done

base_plugin from neutron.db import quota_db from neutron.tests import base class FakePlugin(base_plugin.NeutronDbPluginV2, quota_db.DbQuotaDriver): """A fake plugin class containing all DB methods.""" class TestResource(object): """Describe a test resource for quota checking.""" def __init__(self, name, default): self.name = name self.quota = default @property def default(self): return self.quota class TestDbQuotaDriver(base.BaseTestCase): def setUp(self): super(TestDbQuotaDriver, self).setUp() self.plugin = FakePlugin() self.context = context.get_admin_context() self.addCleanup(db.clear_db) def test_create_quota_limit(self): project = 'prj_test' resource = 'res_test' defaults = {resource: TestResource(resource, 4)} self.plugin.update_quota_limit(self.context, project, resource, 2) quotas = self.plugin.get_tenant_quotas(self.context, defaults, project) self.assertEqual(2, quotas[resource]) def test_update_quota_limit(self): project = 'prj_test' resource = 'res_test' defaults = {resource: TestResource(resource, 4)} self.plugin.update_quota_limit(self.context, project, resource, 2) self.plugin.update_quota_limit(self.context, project, resource, 3) quotas = self.plugin.get_tenant_quotas(self.context, defaults, project) self.assertEqual(3, quotas[resource]) def test_delete_quota_limit(self): project = 'prj_test' resource = 'res_test' defaults = {resource: TestResource(resource, 4)} self.plugin.update_quota_limit(self.context, project, resource, 2) self.plugin.delete_tenant_quota(self.context, project) quotas = self.plugin.get_tenant_quotas(self.context, defaults, project) self.assertEqual(4, quotas[resource]) def test_get_all_quotas(self): project_1 = 'prj_test_1' project_2 = 'prj_test_2' resource_1 = 'res_test_1' resource_2 = 'res_test_2' resources = dict() resources[resource_1] = TestResource(resource_1, 1) resources[resource_2] = TestResource(resource_2, 1) self.plugin.update_quota_limit(self.context, project_1, resource_1, 2) self.plugin.update_quota_limit(self.context, project_2, resource_2, 2) quotas = self.plugin.get_all_quotas(self.context, resources) self.assertEqual(2, len(quotas)) self.assertEqual(3, len(quotas[0])) self.assertEqual(project_1, quotas[0]['tenant_id']) self.assertEqual(2, quotas[0][resource_1]) self.assertEqual(1, quotas[0][resource_2]) self.assertEqual(3, len(quotas[0])) self.assertEqual(project_2, quotas[1]['tenant_id']) def test_limit_check(self): project = 'prj_test' resource = 'res_test' resources = dict() resources[resource] = TestResource(resource, 2) values = dict() values[resource] = 1 self.plugin.update_quota_limit(self.context, project, resource, 2) self.plugin.limit_check(self.context, project, resources, values) def test_limit_check_over_quota(self): project = 'prj_test' resource = 'res_test' resources = dict() resources[resource] = TestResource(resource, 2) values = dict() values[resource] = 3 self.plugin.update_quota_limit(self.context, project, resource, 2) self.assertRaises(exceptions.OverQuota, self.plugin.limit_check, context.get_admin_context(), project, resources, values) def test_limit_check_equals_to_quota(self): project = 'prj_test' resource = 'res_test' resources = dict() resources[resource] = TestResource(resource, 2) values = dict() values[resource] = 2 self.plugin.update_quota_limit(self.context, project, resource, 2) self.plugin.limit_check(self.context, project, resources, values) def test_limit_check_value_lower_than_zero(self): project = 'prj_test' resource = 'res_test' resources = dict() resources[resource] = TestResource(resource, 2) values = dict() values[resource] = -1 self.plugin.update_quota_limit(self.context, project, resource, 2) self.assertRaises(exceptions.InvalidQuotaValue, self.plugin.limit_check, context.get_admin_context(), project, resources, values) def test_limit_check_wrong_values_size(self): project = 'prj_test' resource_1 = 'res_test_1' resource_2 = 'res_test_2' resources = dict() resources[resource_1] = TestResource(resource_1, 2) values = dict() values[resource_1] = 1 values[resource_2] = 1 self.plugin.update_quota_limit(self.context, project, resource_1, 2) self.assertRaises(exceptions.QuotaResourceUnknown, self.plugin.limit_check, context.get_admin_context(), project, resources, values)
